Title: Toward blockchain based electronic health record management with fine grained attribute based encryption and decentralized storage mechanisms
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Scientific Reports
volume 15, Article number: 34542 (2025)
            Cite this article


Current Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems exhibit several critical drawbacks, including significant vulnerabilities in security, privacy, and scalability. Traditional centralized databases are highly susceptible to cyber attacks, data breaches, and unauthorized access, posing severe risks to the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive patient information. In addition, these systems often face interoperability issues, which hinder seamless information sharing and access among healthcare providers. The absence of a unified and secure framework exacerbates these problems, leading to operational inefficiencies and increased administrative costs in the management of health records. This study introduces an innovative framework designed to overcome these challenges by integrating blockchain technology with the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). The proposed EHRChain solution leverages attribute-based encryption to provide fine-grained access control, ensuring that only authorized users can retrieve and decrypt medical records. The IPFS framework eliminates single points of failure by storing encrypted data in a decentralized fashion, thus increasing the resilience of the system to cyber attacks. Incorporating blockchain technology ensures the immutability and traceability of medical data, significantly reducing the risks of data tampering. Performance evaluations using real data set simulation demonstrate the efficiency and feasibility of our framework, highlighting its potential to revolutionize the handling of electronic medical records. This study not only underscores the advantages of integrating blockchain with EHR systems but also presents a scalable and secure solution tailored to meet the demands of modern healthcare infrastructures. Our approach promises to improve data security, improve interoperability, and reduce operational inefficiencies, leading to a new standard in electronic health records.

With the emergence of Internet of Medical Things (IoMT)1, the volume of medical data generated daily has increased dramatically. As the healthcare sector transitions from traditional paper-based charts to Electronic Health Record (EHR), various solutions have been implemented to manage these records efficiently, aiming to enhance patient safety by preventing errors and increasing information accessibility. EHR2, not only serve as legal evidence and tools for predicting and preventing infectious diseases but also enable physicians to reflect on and share treatment experiences with patients in real-time. By 20253, it is projected that electronic storage will encompass at least 15% of patient medical records, marking a 110% increase from 2018 levels.

Typically, medical institutions rely on third-party servers, like cloud servers, to manage encrypted data, which helps reduce computational costs and save space while facilitating efficient data retrieval4. However, the sharing of electronic medical data among medical facilities, though beneficial for providing immediate feedback on patient responses to treatment, raises serious privacy concerns. Once shared, this data is susceptible to illegal misuse, which could compromise patient privacy. Ensuring proper control over access to patient medical records is of paramount importance, with attribute-based encryption (ABE) emerging as a key technique for enforcing access control5. According to reports from the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)6 and the Journal of Healthcare Security7, approximately 81% of healthcare records of Americans have been compromised between 2009 and 2023. In 2023 alone, data breach costs for healthcare organizations reached a record $7, 13 million, a 10% increase over the previous year. These security and privacy breaches present substantial barriers to the effective management and sharing of health records. Thus, there is an urgent need for innovative solutions that ensure the secure and controlled sharing of sensitive medical information among different participants without risking data disclosure or manipulation. An efficient data access mechanism is essential to ensure data security and restrict access to authorized users only. Patients should have the autonomy to decide who can access their medical information8.

In recent years, a variety of healthcare applications have been developed that leverage blockchain technology. Azaria et al. introduced MedRec, the first functional shared Electronic Health Record (EHR) system that utilizes blockchain, although it raises concerns related to confidentiality and privacy9. FHIRChain, a system similar to MedRec, uses cryptographic techniques to encrypt and securely share data among clinicians10. Another framework proposed by Dubovitskaya et al. shares similarities with MedRec, allowing patients to share their health records but lacking a mechanism for consent revocation management11. The Centralized Electronic Health Record systems exhibit significant architectural limitations, as demonstrated in Fig. 1. The dependence on opaque third-party storage solutions creates inherent vulnerabilities in data governance, with users lacking visibility into data location and access patterns. These security concerns, visualized in Fig. 1, include risks of false data injection and system compromises that undermine healthcare data integrity.

Challenges in electronic health record (EHR) storage using centralized approach.

In contrast, MedShare utilizes blockchain technology to enforce access control and manage health data that is stored on the cloud but faces the challenge of scalability12. Current EHR management schemes13,14 suffer from a number of limitations, indicating demand for progressive solutions. First, there is a major security and privacy risk with the dependence on centralized third-party servers, such as cloud servers. Such centralized systems are susceptible to all sorts of cyber threats such as data breaches and hacker attacks. Healthcare data breaches have recently surged, highlighting the critical need to act upon these vulnerabilities. These challenges are further compounded by the inability of existing systems to ensure data privacy and access control. Such critical medical information can be stored in a centralized database and is vulnerable to unauthorized access and input. When data breaches are leaked, patient privacy is at risk, and even worse, the validity and confidentiality of medical records are called into question. Moreover, the absence of comprehensive systems to share and recover medical information safely restricts collaboration between healthcare providers with EHR to improve patient health.

With the advent of blockchain technology15 presents a transformative approach to tackling challenges in healthcare by enabling the secure, tamper-resistant, and decentralized storage of medical records. To mitigate these limitations, we developed a permissionless blockchain-based decentralized system that demonstrates superior performance in terms of response time, processing capacity, and success rate compared to traditional solutions16. Additionally, adopting a blockchain-based model can lead to reduced expenditures related to data administration and inter-institutional data exchange. This blockchain framework is particularly advantageous for enterprise-level applications, including healthcare, as it aligns with the current practices of hospitals and governmental regulatory authorities responsible for generating, overseeing, and regulating healthcare-related data. In the system we propose, access control is managed via the blockchain, while the medical data itself is securely stored in a decentralized file system, specifically the Interplanetary File System (IPFS). In contrast to conventional systems that centralize data, this design improves the system's resilience against security breaches, including Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks and data integrity threats.

The deficiencies of current medical record systems will have to be resolved by innovative and practical methodologies in medical record management17 A Potential Solution: Decentralization The central house of blockchain technology accompanied with decentralized file storage like IPFS. By leveraging the natural security properties of blockchain and the distributed nature of the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), this approach aims to enhance confidentiality, integrity, and access to Electronic Health Records (EHR). Additionally, by integrating attribute-based encryption (ABE) into this framework, access to sensitive medical information is restricted to authorized users, thereby mitigating the threats of unauthorized access and compromising patient confidentiality. Not only does this strategy cut down on expenses surrounding the management and sharing of information, it makes use of blockchain so the medical histories are saved securely in a way that ensures they cannot be tampered with, and spread out across multiple systems.

The purpose of this article is to emphasize the significant gaps and weaknesses present in modern EHR systems18,19,20. Despite the ongoing adoption of EHR with the goal of optimizing healthcare delivery, existing centralized architectures expose healthcare data to substantial security and privacy risks. According to a recent research21, over 70%of healthcare organizations have suffered a data breach at one point in time, resulting in the exposure of millions of patient data. Additionally, HIPAA violations have also seen a rise, and data breaches in the healthcare sector accounts for 45% of all breaches in 2024 to date. Sadly, these alarming statistics illustrate the failings of centralized EHR systems that leave sensitive patient information exposed. Moreover, the rise of cybercriminal attacks in healthcare environments highlights the necessity for more secure and resilient solutions. Traditional security solutions are becoming insufficient to address the sophisticated threats that now target the healthcare industry22.

This paper demonstrates how a hybrid solution has been incorporated into medical record management that is securing medical records while also giving patients the opportunity to manage their own data. With the use of blockchain, The integration of Distributed File System (IPFS) and advanced data restriction mechanisms aims to address the inherent weaknesses of current systems, ensuring the privacy and integrity of sensitive medical data, thereby achieving the state-of-the-art in healthcare information management.

The key contributions are as follows:

Novel Cryptographic Framework: A novel cryptographic framework is developed to enhance the security and efficiency of attribute-based encryption (ABE) schemes. This framework introduces a more robust mechanism for handling dynamic user attributes, ensuring data privacy and security in decentralized environments.

Verifiable Keyword Search: Our scheme enables efficient retrieval of medical records through a verifiable keyword search mechanism. This allows users to swiftly identify and verify authentic medical records, enhancing reliability.

Fine-Grain Access Control: We implement granular access control mechanisms, assigning distinct access rights based on user attributes. This ensures only authorized individuals can decrypt and access sensitive medical information, enhancing data security and privacy.

Optimized Storage and Computational Costs: Our proposed EHRChain model significantly reduces the storage and computational costs compared to existing solutions. By employing advanced mathematical structures and optimization techniques, we achieve lower costs in key generation, setup, and search operations, as detailed in our experimental results.

First section provides an introduction to the motivations behind this research, outlines the drawbacks of existing systems, and presents the objectives of the study. Section “Related work” delves into the background study concerning the utilization of blockchain and IPFS in healthcare data management. Subsequently, Section “Our proposed EHRChain model” explains the proposed methodology, outlining the attribute-based encryption scheme and its integration with IPFS and blockchain technology. In “Ethereum smart contracts design”, is designed to ensure that the smart contracts are robust, efficient, and secure against various potential threats and vulnerabilities. Section “Result and discussion” details the experimental findings and performance assessment of the proposed system. In “Security analysis”, we discuss the implications of our findings and compare our approach with existing methodologies. Section “Conclusion and future work” presents the conclusions of this study and highlights potential directions for future research in this field.

In the medical industry, there is a high level of confidentiality that requires a high level of protection. Healthcare providers exchange this information frequently6. Participants often have difficulty sharing medical information since they may be exposed or have their data altered during the surgical procedure. In prior research23, efforts have been made to develop innovative blockchain solutions tailored for the storage and exchange of Electronic Health Records (EHR)20. However, some of these proposals have limitations, such as offering only basic privacy controls or advocating for the use of public blockchains with resource-intensive consensus mechanisms24. Other studies suggest utilizing permissioned blockchains for EHR storage, yet they fall short of providing detailed access control for patient information. The healthcare industry will be greatly impacted by blockchain technology. In addition, related studies have been published about blockchain in healthcare.

Blockchain technology17 emerges as a cutting-edge solution facilitating decentralized applications without reliance on a central authority, all while upholding crucial security attributes like data integrity, authenticity, non-repudiation, and accountability.

At its core, the blockchain data structure consists of interconnected blocks, each linked to its predecessor via cryptographic hash functions. The content of each block contributes to the generation of a hash value, which is then included as a reference in the subsequent block. The Bitcoin white paper was published by Satoshi Nakamoto in 200815, which marked a major technical advancement. Nakamoto envisioned a secure and safe money system using distributed ledger technology called the blockchain. Blockchain technology revolutionized the financial industry.

Structure of blockchain network.

In a Merkle Tree, each of its leaf nodes records the hash of the transaction, the value of each node within it is the hash of all its children, and the root node represents the entire tree's signature; a change in data will result in a different hash value as shown in the Fig. 2.

Puneet et al.25 conducted a pioneering study exploring the potential of blockchain technology in revolutionizing the healthcare sector. Their investigation revealed that the healthcare industry is predominantly governed by hospitals, pharmaceutical entities, and various intermediaries. They highlighted data sharing as a pivotal driver for integrating blockchain solutions into healthcare.

Dhasarathan et al. (2024)26 proposed a blockchain-based digital credentialing system for participatory governance using the Hyperledger Fabric platform, as also summarized in Table 1. Their system emphasizes transparent and secure issuance and verification of credentials via smart contracts, improving accountability in governance. The design includes modules for credential management, API integration, and smart contract deployment on permissioned blockchains. While their model demonstrates promising scalability and resilience against tampering, the authors acknowledge limitations such as interoperability challenges, scalability bottlenecks in large deployments, and user adoption barriers in real-world public administration settings. Table 1 provides an overview of existing blockchain-based approaches, outlining their primary contributions and associated limitations. This comparative synthesis serves to contextualize the challenges in current research and underscores the necessity of developing a more secure, scalable, and interoperable framework for electronic health record management.

The study identified four key transformative factors necessitating blockchain adoption in healthcare: digital access rights management, enhanced data availability, expedited access to clinical records, and streamlined patient identity verification. Additionally, the study deliberated on the intricacies of on-chain and off-chain data storage, addressing challenges such as managing voluminous clinical records, ensuring security and privacy, and fostering patient engagement.

Patil et al.,36 have proposed an ABE scheme for encrypting medical records on the cloud. Data on a patient's condition and the department that the doctor practices in were compiled without divulging the specific nature of their condition or their illness. However, the paper uses symmetric encryption, which must be implemented by an entirely transparent Global Authority, which will issue public parameters for the system and generate secret keys for the doctor, which is the main limitation of this scheme. A Hyperledger-based Blockchain system called MediChainTM was developed to manage medical data assets. The system is comprised of three components: an access control module, a data repository off-chain, and a user interface. The hashes of the medical data are placed on the blockchain while the data is stored off-chain on the cloud. This system, however, does not take interoperability into account. To provide integrity to patient records,13 proposed a Blockchain-based handshaking mechanism for integrating an existing cloud-based EHR system with a public Blockchain. There are some issues still associated with these strategies, such as preventing internal malicious activity and being protected from cloud server malfunctions, even though they offer secure cloud storage and fine-grained access control.

Don Charles et al.,27 explores the implementation of a blockchain-based payment system to facilitate a potential emissions trading scheme in the Caribbean region. The author discusses the use of blockchain technology to streamline cross-border transactions and enable efficient trading of emissions allowances. However, a potential shortcoming of this paper may be the lack of in-depth analysis on the practical challenges and feasibility of implementing such a system in the Caribbean context, including regulatory, technical, and economic considerations.

Gaur et al.,28 investigates abusive adversarial agents and attack strategies within cyber-physical systems. It delves into various forms of attacks and strategies employed by adversarial agents to compromise the integrity and security of cyber-physical systems. However, a potential shortcoming of this paper could be the limited exploration of defensive mechanisms or countermeasures to mitigate the identified threats, which could provide a more comprehensive understanding of cybersecurity in cyber-physical systems.

In Table 2, we present a comparative analysis between our proposed approach and the work by Ramesh et al. (2023)31. The table highlights key features crucial for blockchain-enabled Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems, including access control mechanisms, scalability, interoperability, security measures, data integrity, and performance optimizations. Our approach emphasizes multi-factor authentication (MFA) and attribute-based encryption (ABE) for robust access control, off-chain storage to efficiently manage large EHR datasets, and standardized data formats to enhance interoperability. In contrast, Ramesh et al. primarily focus on tamper-proof storage with basic access controls and blockchain-based data integrity. This comparison underscores the advancements and distinctive features of our methodology in addressing critical challenges in secure and scalable EHR management.

Namasudra et al.,24 proposed a decentralized and secure cab sharing system leveraging blockchain technology. It focuses on enhancing trust and security in ride-sharing services while decentralizing control and minimizing the need for intermediaries. However, a potential limitation of this work may be the scalability of blockchain-based systems in handling high transaction volumes and ensuring real-time responsiveness, especially in dynamic transportation environments. Further exploration into optimizing the performance and scalability of blockchain-based cab sharing systems may be necessary to address these challenges. Ramesh et al.31 introduced a blockchain-based solution for efficient and tamper-proof storage of Electronic Health Records (EHR) in decentralized cloud-assisted storage systems. The proposed text introduces a base for storage the use of blockchain to improve the security of EHR data and providing decentralization of storage to reduce single point of failures. However, there may be scalability issues within a blockchain system when it comes to managing vast amounts of EHR data and granting timely access to records in an emergency. Moreover, especially regarding transaction verification and consensus mechanisms, the overhead brought by blockchain could slow down the system negatively affecting efficiency and responsiveness. These challenges require further investigation to improve the performance of blockchain-based EHR storage solutions.

The blockchain-based information management systems, MedBlock6 and MedChain37, support secure and efficient access to electronic medical records. Blockchain technology was used to access medical information. MedBlock was conceived as a system for sharing healthcare data for diagnostic and research purposes. It gives patients access to their healthcare records. However, the adopted approach does not provide complete data privacy protection since local hospitals' databases are involved. Aside from that, MedBlock only holds hospital medical records of patients collected from medical examinations and does not store their physiological conditions. Currently, patients are unable to transfer their healthcare data and reports to the Blockchain network. In23 proposes MedChain as a circumvent to these limitations: a session-based healthcare data sharing system based on blockchain technology. In addition to managing and sharing patients' EHR, MedChain allows for sharing their physiological parameters from connected Internet of Medical Things (IoMT)) devices. Transparency and integrity are guaranteed with MediChain, but accessibility and scalability are seriously limited. Since the patient must manually share and upload data to a blockchain, the availability of the sharing service is dependent on availability. In addition, the proposed solution does not support the expansion of service providers within healthcare organizations.

The blockchain was discussed in the biomedical and healthcare sector in mishra et al.,38. There are several advantages offered by the use of blockchain for biomedical or healthcare domains, including decentralization, persistence of clinical or medical records, data quality control, and continuous access to data as well as secure information being accessible to healthcare stakeholders. Several challenges with blockchain technology include confidentiality, speed, scalability, and malicious attacks, such as 51% of attacks. As sensitive medical and clinical records are stored on these systems, these limitations are critical for the healthcare and biomedical sectors. According to the authors, these issues can be resolved with the use of VPNs (Virtual Private Networks) to ensure privacy, encryption of data, and off-chain storage of sensitive medical data.

In29 proposes a blockchain-based approach for preserving privacy in IoT-enabled healthcare systems. It focuses on leveraging blockchain technology to enhance data security and privacy in healthcare environments. However, a potential limitation of this paper may lie in the practical implementation and scalability of the proposed blockchain-based solution in real-world healthcare settings. Explore whether deploying such a system on large-platform healthcare infrastructures is practical through more conversations on the challenges this may pose. In30 Zheng et al. present another approach to privacy-preserving image recognition in remote sensing which makes use of limited visual cryptography. It aims to achieve better privacy protection for sensitive remote sensing data while facilitating accurate image recognition tasks. Yet, the only restriction this approach may face is with the large-scale remote sensing images and real-time requirements. This is particularly so since they do not always imply greater suitability and efficiency of the proposed method to manage broad and versatile remote sensing image datasets.

Datta et al.,32 present a blockchain-enabled smart contract model that combines consumer electronics and mobile edge computing to protect healthcare transactions. The model proposed in this paper combines blockchain technologies and smart contracts to strengthen security and privacy for healthcare transactions, along with consumer electronics and mobile edge computing for data processing and management. However, one of the limitations of this work can be the intricate nature and interoperability problems related to the introduction of wide-ranging consumer electronics, mobile edge computing, and blockchain technologies into the healthcare domain. To achieve the seamless integration and functionality of the proposed model in real-world healthcare environments, further research and development efforts may be needed.

In the proposed scheme, bilinear mapping is employed as a fundamental component for the implementation of attribute-based encryption (ABE). This choice is motivated by the unique properties and advantages that bilinear mappings offer, particularly in the context of secure and efficient access control mechanisms for electronic medical records (EMRs).

We denote both \(G_{0}\) and \(G_{1}\) as cyclic multiplicative groups composed of large prime numbers \(\rho\). Let \(\rho\) be an element of R and \({\mathscr {Q}}\) be the starting point for these groups, containing an element that maps to \(G_{T}\), the same class of cyclic multiplicative groups, represented by 1. The bilinear mapping \({\hat{e}}\) is defined as \({\hat{e}}: G_{1} \times G_{2} \rightarrow G_{T}\). \({\hat{e}}\) is considered a bilinear map if it satisfies the following criteria18,36: 

Bilinearity:

For any elements \(a, b \in {\mathscr {Z}}^*_{\rho }\), and \(\forall X \in G_0\), \(\forall Y \in G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(a \cdot X, b \cdot Y) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y)^{ab}\).

For any elements \(X, Y, Z \in G_0, G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(XY, Z) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y) \cdot {\hat{e}}(X, Z)\).

For any elements \(X, Y, Z \in G_0, G_1\), \({\hat{e}}(XY, Z) = {\hat{e}}(X, Z) \cdot {\hat{e}}(Y, Z)\).

Nondegeneracy: For any two elements X and Y, there exists at least one element X such that \({\hat{e}}(X \times X) \ne 1\).

Computability: For any elements \(\forall X \in G_0\), \(\forall Y \in G_1\), there exists at least one efficient way to compute \({\hat{e}}(X, Y) \in G_T\).

Let \({\mathscr {S}}\) denote a set of user attributes, represented as \({\mathscr {S}} = \{att_{1}, att_{2}, \ldots , att_{n}\}\). Each attribute \(att_{i}\) in \({\mathscr {S}}\) has a corresponding set \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\) of possible values, where \({\mathscr {L}}_{i} = \{x_{i,1}, x_{i,2}, x_{i,3}, \ldots , x_{i,n}\}\), with n being the total number of possible values for each attribute39. Now, consider \({\mathscr {S}}\) as an attribute set of a user, defined as \({\mathscr {S}} = \{{\mathscr {S}}_{1}, {\mathscr {S}}_{2}, {\mathscr {S}}_{3}, \ldots , {\mathscr {S}}_{n}\}\), where \({\mathscr {S}}_{i}\) corresponds to \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\). An access structure33, denoted by \({\mathscr {W}}\), is defined as \({\mathscr {W}} = \{w_1, w_2, \ldots , w_n\}\), with each \(w_i\) belonging to \({\mathscr {L}}_{i}\). The access policy \({\mathscr {S}}\) satisfies \({\mathscr {W}}\) if and only if \({\mathscr {W}}\) evaluates to 1. Specifically, \({\mathscr {W}} = \lambda _i \in I_{w}\), where the attribute list \({\mathscr {S}}\) is defined as \(\{att_{1}, att_{2}, \ldots , att_{n}\}\), and \(I_{w}\) is given by \(I_{w} = \{i \,|\, 1 \le i \le n, {\mathscr {W}}_i \ne * \}\). We say that \({\mathscr {S}}\) satisfies \({\mathscr {W}}\), denoted by \({\mathscr {S}} \models {\mathscr {W}}\), if \({\mathscr {S}}\) matches \({\mathscr {W}}_{i}\) for all i ranging from 1 to n; otherwise, \({\mathscr {S}} \nvDash {\mathscr {W}}\). It important to note that \({\mathscr {S}} \models {\mathscr {W}}\) if the attribute set \({\mathscr {S}}\) meets the access structure \({\mathscr {W}}\), i.e., \({\mathscr {S}}_{i}\) equals \({\mathscr {W}}_{i}\) for all \(i = \{1, 2, 3, \ldots , n\}\). Conversely, when \({\mathscr {S}}\) does not satisfy \({\mathscr {W}}\), it is represented as \({\mathscr {S}} \nvDash {\mathscr {W}}\).

In the proposed scheme, bilinear mapping is crucial for implementing attribute-based encryption (ABE), chosen for its unique properties that enhance secure and efficient access control for electronic medical records (EMRs). The specific reasons for using bilinear mappings over other hash functions include the following:

Bilinear mappings facilitate the construction of ABE schemes, allowing for fine-grained access control. This means access to encrypted data can be regulated based on the user's attributes rather than their identity, enabling a more nuanced and secure access control mechanism. Additionally, bilinear mappings support the encryption and decryption processes for complex access policies efficiently, which is critical for medical records where different users (e.g., doctors, nurses, administrators) require varying levels of access based on their roles.

The mathematical properties of bilinear maps are essential for ABE. For example, given groups \(G_1\) and \(G_2\) and a target group \(G_T\), a bilinear map \({\hat{e}}: G_1 \times G_2 \rightarrow G_T\) satisfies \({\hat{e}}(a \cdot X, b \cdot Y) = {\hat{e}}(X, Y)^{ab}\) for any elements \(a, b \in {\mathscr {Z}}^*_{\rho }\). This property is crucial for combining user attributes and access policies in a way that allows for efficient encryption and decryption. Furthermore, the nondegeneracy property ensures that there exists at least one pair \((X, Y) \in G_1 \times G_2\) such that \({\hat{e}}(X, Y) \ne 1\), providing meaningful cryptographic results essential for security. The computability property ensures that \({\hat{e}}(X, Y)\) can be computed efficiently for any \(X \in G_1\) and \(Y \in G_2\), which is important for practical implementation and performance.

The security of ABE schemes built on bilinear mappings relies on well-established cryptographic hardness assumptions, such as the Bilinear Diffie-Hellman (BDH) assumption. These assumptions provide strong guarantees against various cryptographic attacks, ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of medical data.

Bilinear mappings also allow for dynamic user management, enabling the addition and revocation of users without requiring re-encryption of existing data. This scalability is vital in a healthcare setting where user roles and permissions frequently change. Furthermore, the scheme can efficiently handle updates to access policies, making it adaptable to changing security requirements and user roles.

In our proposed EHRChain model, four primary entities collaborate to ensure secure and efficient electronic health record management: the blockchain, the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), the medical system (comprising doctors and smart healthcare devices), and the data user system. These components collectively represent the main entities and operational processes that underpin our framework (see Fig. 3).

Our proposed EHRChain framework ensures secure data handling and scalable storage by integrating two core technologies: Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) and the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). ABE provides a fine-grained cryptographic access control mechanism that allows data owners to define access policies based on descriptive user attributes (e.g., role, department, or clearance level). Only users whose attributes satisfy the specified access policy can decrypt the associated data. This enables decentralized and flexible access control, aligning with the complex authorization requirements inherent in healthcare data sharing. For off-chain storage, EHRChain leverages IPFS, a peer-to-peer distributed file system that retrieves content using unique cryptographic hashes instead of traditional location-based addresses. Encrypted patient records are stored on IPFS, while their corresponding hash references are anchored on the blockchain. This design preserves data immutability and integrity, reduces on-chain storage overhead, and ensures efficient data retrieval. Together, ABE and IPFS form the foundational pillars of the EHRChain framework, facilitating privacy-preserving access control and scalable, decentralized storage for secure electronic health record management.

The medical system comprises physicians and smart devices of the system. Doctors are responsible for encrypting and saving medical records. They utilize encryption and indexing algorithms to secure medical records and generate indexes for keywords. The encrypted records are then stored in IPFS, and their hash values, along with IPFS hash addresses, are recorded on the blockchain. System smart devices handle the registration of hospital personnel, assigning secret private keys associated with their attributes.

Data users (DU) can be doctors, nurses, researchers, patients, etc. Each DU is assigned a key pair associated with their attributes by the system. To access medical records, a DU must request access from the hospital. After confirming their attributes meet system access policies, the DU receives a token to search for medical records.

In our scheme, medical data is stored and searched using the Ethereum blockchain platform. Since blockchains are immutable, they are a reliable source for verifying data authenticity and integrity, due to their inability to be arbitrarily modified.

IPFS enables permanent storage and sharing of various types of files. A unique hash value is assigned to each file based on its content. Furthermore, IPFS uses deduplication to effectively avoid redundant data storage. IPFS is used for medical records storage in our scheme.

In our proposed framework (see Fig. 3), a key feature of our proposed EHRChain Model is the incorporation of a fine-grained access control scheme, which ensures that only authorized users can access specific medical records. This access control mechanism is tightly integrated with advanced data encryption techniques, safeguarding sensitive patient information from unauthorized access. We utilize robust key management protocols to securely distribute and manage encryption keys, adding an additional layer of security. Furthermore, EHRChain Model employs a hybrid storage solution where actual medical data is stored in a blockchain-friendly off-chain tool like IPFS (InterPlanetary File System). The hash generated from storing data on IPFS is then placed on the blockchain. This approach combines the immutable and transparent properties of blockchain with the scalable and efficient storage capabilities of IPFS, ensuring both security and efficiency in managing large volumes of medical data.

Our proposed system model securely manages Electronic Health Record (EHR) using Ethereum blockchain and IPFS. Medical records are encrypted and stored on IPFS, with the hash address recorded on the blockchain. Authorized users can retrieve and decrypt the records, ensuring data integrity and confidentiality through cryptographic techniques.

This case study demonstrates the functionality and security features of our proposed EHRChain Model in real-world applications.

Step 1: The process begins with Dr. Bob documenting the necessary information of the patient, Alice. This information, denoted as \(P\), includes all relevant medical details.

Step 2:  Once the documentation is complete, Dr. Bob provides Alice with a private key, denoted as \(K_p\).

Step 3:  Alice's information \(P\) is then converted into a PDF document using a backend Node.js service.

Step 4:  The encrypted MongoDB symmetric key, denoted as \(E(K_{sym})\), is retrieved and decrypted using Dr. Bob's private key \(K_{bob}\).

where \(D_{K_{bob}}\) represents the decryption function using Dr. Bob's private key.

Step 5:  The symmetric key \(K_{sym}\) is then used to encrypt the PDF file.

where \(E_{K_{sym}}\) represents the encryption function using the symmetric key.

Step 6:  The encrypted PDF file \(E_{\text {PDF}}\) is stored on the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS). IPFS generates a Content Identifier (CID) for the stored file.

Step 7:  The generated CID is then stored in a block on the Ethereum blockchain network as part of a transaction.

This transaction ensures that the CID and, therefore,fore, the linencrypted patient information is immutable and securely stored on blockchain.

Step 8:  To secure the storage of a medical record R, the physician (e.g. Dr. Bob) initiates the encryption process. The medical record R is encrypted and signed to produce CT and sigR respectively. This encrypted record \(CT^* = (CT, sigR)\) is stored in IPFS, which provides a hash address h corresponding to \(CT^*\). Furthermore, the hash value hR of the medical record and an encrypted hash address h0 are transmitted to the blockchain as part of a transaction, generating a block ID.

Step 9:  When Alice needs to access her medical records, she sends an access request with keywords to the hospital. Upon verification, the system's smart contract issues a search token \(STw = (ID, h, \gamma )\) to the authorized Data User (DU), such as Alice or a healthcare provider. The block ID in the search token allows the DU to read the hash value h from the corresponding block on the blockchain. By comparing h with the hash address stored on the blockchain,kchain,kchain,kchain, the DU verifies the integrity of the record. Once validated, the DU retrieves the encrypted medical record \(CT^*\) from IPFS using the hash address h and decrypts it using their private key to access the original medical information. The proposed EHRChain model ensures that Alice's patient information is securely documented, encrypted, and stored in a decentralized manner, leveraging the security and transparency of blockchain technology.

The EHRChain framework is architected to support interoperability with widely recognized Electronic Health Record (EHR) standards, specifically Health Level Seven (HL7) and Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR). This interoperability is achieved through standardized API interfaces and a data translation layer capable of mapping blockchain-anchored metadata and IPFS-stored encrypted patient records into FHIR-compliant JSON resources message formats.

During the retrieval process, the framework queries the blockchain to obtain the corresponding IPFS content identifier, fetches the encrypted data, and converts them into a FHIR Patient or Observation resource for seamless integration with existing hospital information systems. In contrast, clinical data originating in HL7 format are processed by the ingestion module, which parses HL7 segments and maps them to the standardized schema of EHRChain prior to encryption and offline storage. By incorporating these mechanisms, EHRChain enables healthcare organizations to integrate the proposed blockchain-based system without disrupting existing EHR infrastructures, while maintaining data portability, regulatory compliance, and alignment with established interoperability frameworks.

In our proposed framework (see Fig. 4), administrators and users interact through a decentralized application (DApp). Users, such as doctors and patients, are assigned roles defined by the system administrator, typically a hospital administrator. These roles govern granular access to the system's functionalities and data, ensuring secure and controlled operations. This case study illustrates the real-world application of our proposed EHRChain Model. In our scheme, we simulate the process of a patient Alice, who has been admitted to the hospital and then returns home. This detailed process demonstrates the practical application of our proposedEHRChain Model, ensuring secure, efficient, and controlled access to medical records in a real-world healthcare setting.

EHRChain Model as an example, where administrators and users, including doctors and patients, interact through a decentralized application (DApp) where roles defined by the system administrator ensure secure and controlled access to medical data.

This case study demonstrates the functionality and security features of our proposed EHRChain Model in real-world applications. The following are the detailed steps to complete the process:

The administrator assigns roles, which include the Role Name and Account Address of the user, as shown in Fig. 4. Each user in the system has a role name and an account address. When a user requests an operation after roles have been assigned, the system checks the user's account address and role name from the Roles List. The functions can be performed if the validation is successful. The system then stores the information on the Ethereum Blockchain, which processes transactions for that information. Upon successful transaction confirmation, the system receives a success message from the blockchain layer, visible on the DApp browser, the interface of the proposed framework.

Given a security parameter \(\lambda\), the system initially generates a set of public parameters \((G1, G2, GT, \lambda , e, p, g1, g2)\), where G1 and G2 denote two cyclic multiplicative groups with prime order p. The elements g1 and g2 serve as generators for G1 and G2 respectively, with \(g1 \in G1\) and \(g2 \in G2\). Additionally, \(e: G1 \times G2 \rightarrow GT\) represents the bilinear map. Furthermore, a collision-resistant hash function \(H: \{0, 1\}^{\lambda } \rightarrow {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) is established.

Step 1: Registration and Diagnosis - Dr. Bob, a physician at the General Hospital, registers the patient Alice and generates a medical record R for him. The attributes for Alice are: \(S = \{name: Alice, age: 28, gender: male, identity: patient\}\), based on which a public-private key pair is generated.

Subsequently, the system proceeds to randomly select parameters \(\alpha , \beta , \sigma \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\). For each attribute i, where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), the system generates random values \(a_{i,t} \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\), where \(m_i\) denotes the total number of possible values for attribute i. For instance, if \(i = 1\) corresponds to a doctor, \(i = 2\) to a nurse, and \(i = 3\) to an expert, then \(m_1\) represents the total count of doctors, and \(m_3\) represents the total count of experts.

Finally, the system obtains the public key \(mpk = (G_P, e(g1, g2), H)\) and the master key msk.

The equation outlines the setup process for a cryptographic system utilizing bilinear pairings and random parameter generation. It initializes public parameters including cyclic multiplicative groups G1 and G2 with prime order p, along with generators g1 and g2. A bilinear map e and a hash function H are established. Random parameters \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), and \(\sigma\) are chosen, along with attribute-specific random values \(a_{i,t}\). Finally, the system computes the public key mpk and the master key msk incorporating these parameters.

The system has roles and account addresses for each user. A user's account address and role name are checked from the Roles List when they request an operation after roles have been assigned. If the validation succeeds, the functions can be performed. Meanwhile, the DU generates a search request utilizing its search private key and subsequently decrypts the medical records using its corresponding secret private key, which is linked to its set of attributes.

Initially, the system computes \(Y = e(g1, g2)^{\alpha }\), \(B = g^{\beta }_1\), \(u_1 = g^{\sigma }_1\), and \(A_{i,t} = g^{a_{i,t}}\), where \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). Subsequently, it derives the public-private key pair (pko, sko) as follows:

In Step 1, the system generates a public-private key pair for the Doctor. It computes \(Y = e(g1, g2)^{\alpha }\), \(B = g^{\beta }1\), \(u_1 = g^{\sigma }1\), and \(A{i,t} = g^{a{i,t}}\), where \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\). The public-private key pair (pko, sko) is then derived as \(pko = (Y, B, u_1, A_{i,t}, 1 \le t \le m_i, 1 \le i \le m_g)\). and

The equation represents the private key components for the Doctor, denoted as \(\text {sko}\). It includes parameters such as \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\sigma\), and \(a_{i,t}\) for \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\).

The system randomly selects \(s \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) and computes \(D_1 = g^s_2\), \(u_2 = g^{\sigma }_2\), and \(D_2 = \prod _{t=1}^{m_i} u^{a_{i,t}}_2\). Additionally, it selects two random numbers \(x_i, \lambda _i \in {\mathbb {Z}}^*_p\), where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), and computes \(x = \sum _{i=1}^{m_g} x_i\), along with \(d_0 = g^{\alpha \cdot x \cdot \beta }\).

For each attribute number i where \(1 \le i \le m_g\), when \(S_i = v_{i,t}\), it computes \(d_{i,1} = g^{x_i}_2 \cdot A_{i,t}^{\lambda _i}\), \(d_{i,2} = g^{\lambda _i}_2\), resulting in the private key pair (sku, skS):

This equation represents the private key components for the Doctor, denoted as sko. It includes parameters such as \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\sigma\), and \(a_{i,t}\) for \(1 \le t \le m_i\) and \(1 \le i \le m_g\).

The doctor prepares a medical record R for the Data User (DU) after diagnosing the \(DU's\) condition and then uploads the medical record R onto the IPFS. Initially, to encrypt the medical record R, the doctor defines the ciphertext policy as \(W = [W_1, W_2,..., W_m]\). Random values \(r_i\) are selected for each attribute number i, and the ciphertext CT is computed based on the policy and associated attributes. Moreover, the doctor signs the ciphertext to ensure its authenticity.

Next, the doctor uploads \(CT^* = (CT, sigR)\) via IPFS, which provides h for \(CT^*\). After storing medical records on the blockchain, the doctor logs the process. To obtain \(h_R = \text {SHA256}(h_R)\), he hashes the medical record R using the SHA256 hash function. With respect to h, he picks randomly \(\gamma \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) to calculate \(h_0 = h^\gamma\). After broadcasting a transaction and obtaining the block ID, he records the tuple \((h_R, h_0)\) on the blockchain.

To facilitate searching, the Doctor must create indexes for the stored medical records. Initially, he extracts the keyword \(w = (w_1, w_2,..., w_m)\) from the medical record R. Subsequently, he chooses a random value \(y \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p^*\) and calculates \(I_1 = g^y \cdot H(w_1||w_2||\dots ||w_m)\) and \(I_2 = u_1 \cdot \prod _{i,t \in W_i} A_{i,t}^y\). Consequently, the Doctor obtains the index as \(I = (I_1, I_2)\).

In this phase, the Data User (DU) intends to search for the keyword \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Initially, the DU forwards a search request to the hospital. Upon identity verification of the DU by the system's smart device, a search token is provided.

The DU forwards a request to the hospital containing the keyword \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Subsequently, the DU randomly selects \(z \in {\mathbb {Z}}_p\) and computes \(T_1 = D_{z,H}(w_{01}||w_{02}||\dots ||w_{0m})\) and \(T_2 = D_z^2\). The request \((T_1, T_2)\) is then sent to the hospital.

As soon as the Data User (DU) requests access, a test is performed by the smart device to determine whether the DU has authorization to access medical records containing \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Initially, the system's smart device evaluates whether \(e(I_1, T_2)\) equals \(e(I_2, T_1)\). If \(e(I_1, T_2) = e(I_2, T_1)\), it signifies that the DU has permission to access the medical records containing the keywords \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\). Afterward, the system's smart device sends \(ST_w = (ID, h, \gamma )\) to the DU, containing the block ID, the hash address h, and the random value \(\gamma\).

On the basis of the block ID provided in the search token \(ST_w\), the DU retrieves the tuple \((h_R, h_0)\) from the blockchain. In the next step, he calculates \(h_{00} = h^\gamma\) alongside \(h_0\) to validate the accuracy of h. If \(h_{00} = h_0\), he retrieves medical records which contain the keyphrase \(w_0 = (w_{01}, w_{02},..., w_{0m})\) from the IPFS. Using the SHA256 hash function, the DU hashes the decrypted medical record \(R'\) and compares it to the blockchain hash value. Medical records R that \(h_{[0R]} = h_R\) can be considered original if \(h_{[0R]} = h_R\).

The decryption operation in our proposed scheme is governed by a pairing-based computation, where the final result \(R'\) is derived by combining ciphertext components with user-specific decryption keys, as illustrated in Eq. (6). Once the Data User (DU) receives the ciphertext \(CT = (C_0, C_0, (C_{i,1}, C_{i,t,2})_{1 \le t \le m_i, 1 \le i \le m})\), he proceeds to decrypt it using his secure private key \(sk_S\). For each attribute number i, \(C'_{i,t,2} = C_{i,t,2}\) where \(S_i = (v_i, t_i)\). The decrypted medical record \(R'\) is computed as:

As shown in Eq. (6), the decryption result \(R'\) is computed through bilinear pairings over the ciphertext components and corresponding secret keys.

Smart contracts play a pivotal role in our DApp ecosystem, enabling essential operations and interactions. Our framework includes the following contracts:

Patient Records: Facilitating CRUD operations on patient records, ensuring secure and tamper-proof management.

Roles: Regulating user access and permissions within the DApp, maintaining data integrity and privacy.

These contracts are instrumental in realizing the functionalities of our proposed framework, ensuring seamless interactions and robust data management. The primary smart contract in our system is responsible for executing CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on patient records while also defining access roles.

Secondly, the smart contract, known as Roles, comes from the OpenZeppel in library40, specifically the Asset library. This library offers tested and community-reviewed code, ensuring reliability. The Roles contract provides a granular role definition mechanism, making it an ideal choice for our system. In the following algorithm, we outline the operations and associated conditions of the Patient Records smart contract.

The following algorithms outline the functioning of the smart contract dedicated to patient records. It comprises five functions: role definition, addition, viewing, updating, and deletion of records. These functions are accessible to administrators and other system users.

The algorithm described in Algorithm 1 defines a function named AddPatientRecord, which is intended to be executed within a smart contract. This function is designed to facilitate the addition of new patient records to a healthcare system. It accepts as input the variables necessary to include data in a patient's record. Similar to the previous algorithm, this function begins by verifying the identity of the caller (msg.sender) to ensure that only authorized users, specifically doctors, can execute this function. If the caller is indeed a doctor, the function proceeds to insert the provided data into the specific patient's record. This typically involves creating a new entry in the database or appending the provided information to an existing patient record. However, if the caller is not identified as a doctor, the function terminates the session, preventing unauthorized access to the system. Overall, this algorithm provides a secure and controlled mechanism for adding new patient records within a blockchain-based healthcare system.

Add data: smart contract function

The algorithm described in Algorithm 2 defines a function named UpdatePatientRecord, which is intended to be executed within a smart contract. This function is designed to facilitate the updating of patient records in a secure and controlled manner.It given input to the values it needs to change within a patient's record. When invoked, the function first checks the identity of its caller (the msg. sender, so that only authorized users can use this function. It is checking, specifically, if the caller is a doctor. Assuming the caller is a doctor, the function then validates the supplied patient id and title against a stored patient. This step validates whether the provided doctor can update data of the specified patient. If the identifier and designation match what are currently stored in the patient record, the function goes ahead and updates the data. For example, this usually means updating the same fields in the patient record as you can provide input variables. If, on the other hand, the record is successfully changed, a call to the function returns a signal of success. If, in contrast, either the identifier or designation offered is inconsistent with the patient's record, the function returns a failure signal, indicating that the update had not been executed. Moreover, if the caller fails to identify himself or herself as a doctor, the function ends the session, denying them access to data such as patient records. This algorithm ensures up to date patient data without compromising patient confidentiality.

Update data: smart contract function

Algorithm 3 describes an algorithm that implements a function called AbortSession that can be run in a smart contract. It is designed for logging out from the health care system. This function does not require any input parameters like previous algorithms as it will end the ongoing session. What the function does is simply log you out or end your active session when you run it This is critical for maintaining security and privacy in the healthcare system, as users should be able to log out when they have completed their tasks or when they need to log out from the system. A simple in-session session termination within the smart contract would help improve the overall security and user experience of the healthcare application.

Abort session: smart contract function

The function implemented in Algorithm 4 is called DeletePatientRecord and it would be executed in a smart contract to delete patient records within the healthcare system. It takes the patient's ID, so it can go through the database and locate the exact record to delete.

This checks whether the requestor of the request is authorized, i.e., in the case the requestor is a doctor. Once confirmed to be a doctor, the function still checks if the provided patient identifier matches the patient that needs to be deleted from the registry. If the identifiers match, the function goes ahead and deletes the patient record and returns a success message. However, if the identifiers do not match, it means that the provided identifier does not correspond to an existing record so the function returns a failure message. If the sender is not, the function stops immediately to avoid an unauthorized doctor access. It helps protect the integrity and privacy of patient data for authorized medical personnel, who may, if need be, remove patient records while ensuring the protection of sensitive healthcare data.

Delete data: smart contract function

This pivotal section delves into the performance evaluation of the proposed framework, aimed at mitigating the risks associated with the adoption of this innovative technology. Through rigorous testing and analysis, we assess the effectiveness, efficiency, and robustness of the framework in addressing key challenges and vulnerabilities inherent in the adoption of novel technologies like blockchain-based solutions.

This crucial section focuses on the performance metrics of the suggested framework in minimizing the associated risks of implementing this sophisticated technology. Based on testing and assessment we investigate how well the framework quantities the challenges and vulnerabilities in the new technology, including efficiency, network/computation cost and robustness of solution relative to using a blockchain-based solution.

The experiment setup is crucial in evaluating the functionality and efficiency of any framework or system. For our study, we prepared an experimental set-up specifically designed for performance testing in order to reproduce the findings correctly and without distortion. Experimental Setup: The experiment environment includes the hardware configuration, software tools, transaction dataset, evaluation metrics, and performance evaluation methods.

All performance tests are done in a high-end desktop machine where we have more than sufficient processors, RAM, and so on. Hardware Configuration: Intel Core i7-6498DU CPU at 2.50GHz (base) and up to 2.60GHz (turbo boost) For RAM, the system sported 8.00 GB, or enough memory to run demanding computational processes. The Windows 10 operating system, specifically the 64-bit variant, was used for the desktop computer to test for compatibility and stability.

To carry out the simulation, deployment, and evaluation of the proposed framework, development tools used in the experimental environment are important that systematically ensured the correct implementation of the simulation and experimental processes. We were able to leverage different tools which served for the different purposes and contributed to the overall process of performance testing.

Using Remix – an online Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for writing, compiling, and deploying Ethereum smart contracts – made it possible to conduct programming in an easy to use interface. Simulation and development of the smart contracts that forms our suggested framework using Remix IDE With its web-based interface, it facilitated direct interaction with the Ethereum blockchain, allowing for on-spot testing and debugging of smart contracts.

For the dApp, we use Metamask41, an Ethereum browser extension that is used as a digital wallet and as a bridge between web browsers and the Ethereum blockchain. In order to deploy and test the smart contracts on the Ethereum test network (Rinkby), we use Metamask. This made signing and broadcasting transactions easy and allowed the execution of smart contracts in the sandbox, simplified by its integration with different web browsers.

The proposed framework was built around Solidity, the programming language for writing smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain. Smart Contract Implementation - Solidity We used Solidity to implement the logic and functionality of smart contracts governing our proposed system. We utilized Solidity for our smart contracts and integrated them with Remix IDE to ensure the integrity of transactional items we were dealing with this way, adding the final layer of usability to our experimental environment.

To simulate a realistic healthcare data environment, we generated a synthetic dataset comprising 5,000 electronic health record (EHR) transactions. Each transaction emulates common operations in a decentralized medical data management system, such as role assignment, patient record creation, update, retrieval, and deletion. The dataset was constructed to reflect typical healthcare system dynamics, incorporating various user roles (e.g., physicians, administrative staff, and data users) and record attributes such as patient identifiers, medical categories, timestamps, access privileges, and digital signatures.

The simulated transactions were subjected to Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) based on dynamic policy structures and were subsequently offloaded to IPFS for decentralized storage. Only the cryptographic hashes of these files were anchored to the Ethereum testnet, mimicking real-world system behavior while ensuring system efficiency and privacy compliance. This dataset model enabled us to assess how well the proposed EHRChain framework handles concurrent access, access control enforcement, and decentralized data storage under realistic operational conditions.

The experimental evaluation was guided by a multi-dimensional set of performance criteria aimed at assessing the system's responsiveness, scalability, and resource efficiency under varied workloads. The core evaluation metrics include:

Execution Time: This metric quantifies the temporal duration between the submission of a smart contract transaction and its successful confirmation on the blockchain. It reflects the computational and network delays associated with contract deployment and function invocation.

Throughput (Transactions/sec): Defined as the average number of successfully processed transactions per unit time. This measures the system's capacity to handle concurrent operations, a critical factor in scalable healthcare infrastructure.

Latency: Measured as the delay between a user-initiated request and the receipt of a system response. This includes smart contract call delays and consensus-related propagation times across the blockchain network.

Gas Consumption and Transaction Fees: Each smart contract function incurs a gas cost, which is converted into Ether based on current gas prices. We calculated the financial cost of deploying and executing AssignRoles, AddRecord, ViewRecord, UpdateRecord, and DeleteRecord operations to analyze the cost-effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

Storage Overhead: We evaluated the memory footprint introduced by storing encrypted EHRs on IPFS and maintaining their metadata on-chain. The analysis includes transaction payload sizes and their effect on blockchain bloat and off-chain storage scalability.

The experimental setup leveraged Remix IDE42 for Solidity-based smart contract testing, Metamask for transaction signing41, and the Ethereum Rinkeby testnet for blockchain emulation. Apache JMeter was configured to simulate multi-user access patterns and concurrency levels ranging from 100 to 500 simultaneous users. Performance profiling was conducted in real time, enabling us to benchmark execution time variations, stress-test system throughput, and evaluate responsiveness under transactional load. This comprehensive performance evaluation demonstrates the viability of our framework for secure, scalable, and decentralized healthcare data management in practical deployment scenarios.

The performance measurement method comprises analysis of transaction data and transaction information during the execution of smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain. These transaction metrics are the transaction implementation time (tx1) and the transaction completion time (tx2). Transaction deployment time was the time taken to deploy a smart contract on the Ethereum blockchain, while Transaction Completion Time was the time needed for a transaction to complete and to be confirmed by the blockchain network.

We perform simulations of real-world scenarios to evaluate how well our custom framework performs under the different quoting conditions. For this application, Apache JMeter was used as a performance testing tool to analyze the application's performance. To run these tests, we set up Apache JMeter to simulate multiple concurrent users using the system at the same time and record execution time, throughput, and latency as performance metrics. Through a rigorous analysis of the performance data and an in-depth evaluation of the framework, we obtained meaningful insights into its scalability, efficiency, and reliability.

The average time taken to execute various transactions on the blockchain was measured. For instance, single-user functions such as “Assign Roles”, “Add Patient Records”, and “View Patient Records” exhibited execution times of approximately 18.29 s, 1 min 48 s, and 50 s respectively. These times increased proportionally with the number of concurrent users, demonstrating the scalability of our framework.

The throughput of the system, represented in KB/sec, was assessed using Apache JMeter. Simulations were conducted with user loads ranging from 100 to 500. The results, depicted in Fig. 5, show the system's ability to handle varying loads efficiently.

Throughput of the our proposed EHRChain framework.

Latency, defined as the delay between sending a request and receiving a response, was evaluated using JMeter. Latency is measured in milliseconds.

Average latency of our proposed EHRChain framework.

The average latency, or the delay between sending a request and receiving a response, was also evaluated using JMeter. The highest recorded latency in our experiments was 14 milliseconds, as shown in Fig. 6. This metric is crucial for understanding the system's responsiveness under different conditions.

The data payload is encoded in hexadecimal format and consists of bytes. In this section, we will discuss two Algorithm functions that we can use to gain a deeper understanding of data payload included in transactions.

An optional data payload field is used when interacting with contract functions during a transaction. It consists of two parts:

Function Selector

Function Arguments

Keccak-256 hash identifies a smart contract function by the first four bytes of the function selector. There are several types of static and dynamic elements in the function arguments, each of which is encoded differently in the payload. For an understanding of how data is generated, let us examine the payload from the Define Roles function in Algorithms. As a first step, we will separate the argument selector from the function selector. Function selectors are function signatures, such as the following: 0x 28e4a6af  In this case, the function selector represents the hashed string of DefineRoles(address,uint256). In the data payload, the arguments are added after the function selector. This argument includes the new account address and the new role.

Convert all the inputs into their hexadecimal representations and concatenate all this data. The payload is included in the transaction afterward. Lastly, by looking at the data payload we can get useful information about state changes in Ethereum transactions and smart contracts. When we can split the transaction payloads into their function selector and function arguments, we get a more in-depth look at how the smart contracts work. This emphasizes allows us to optimize the encoding and processing of these elements, further improving transaction efficiency. We use the types of the arguments in our functions to differentiate static and dynamic types, which allows us to use our channels more effectively as an encoding mechanism. This difference is an important one for reducing the amount of data sent in each payload and thus for enhancing the throughput of Ethereum transactions. Such an estimation is critically important to the understanding and management of the economic side of implementing blockchain-based solutions in healthcare.

The performance of the proposed EHRChain framework was rigorously evaluated with respect to two primary operational metrics: scalability, quantified as Transactions Per Second (TPS), and latency, defined as the mean transaction finality time from request submission to blockchain confirmation. Comparative analysis was conducted against two representative blockchain-based EHR management models: (i) Ramesh et al. (2023)31, which employs a fully on-chain architecture with Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT), and (ii) Sharma et al. (2024)43, which adopts a blockchain–cloud hybrid approach leveraging conventional symmetric encryption for off-chain data handling. The performance of the proposed EHRChain framework was evaluated against existing approaches by Ramesh et al. (2023) and Sharma et al. (2024). As illustrated in Fig. 8, EHRChain consistently achieves higher throughput in terms of transactions per second while maintaining significantly lower latency under varying concurrent user loads. This demonstrates the scalability and efficiency of our framework compared to prior solutions.

Performance comparison between EHRChain, Ramesh et al. (2023), and Sharma et al. (2024). (a) Scalability in TPS. (b) Average transaction latency in milliseconds.

EHRChain was deployed with a hybrid PoS+PBFT consensus protocol and integrated with the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) for off-chain storage. Performance benchmarking was conducted using the Hyperledger Caliper framework, with simulated transaction loads of 100, 300, and 500 concurrent requests. To ensure methodological rigor, identical transaction payloads and system configurations were applied across all comparative models. EHRChain demonstrated superior throughput characteristics under increasing workloads. At 500 concurrent transactions, the framework sustained a throughput of 248 TPS, corresponding to a 7.4% degradation relative to the 100-user baseline (268 TPS). By contrast, Sharma et al.43 model achieved 198 TPS (12.2% degradation), while Ramesh et al.31 fully on-chain system recorded 143 TPS (21.6% degradation). These results indicate that the decoupling of bulk EHR data from on-chain storage significantly mitigates consensus bottlenecks, thereby enhancing scalability.

EHRChain also outperformed the baseline systems in transaction finality time. At peak load, the average latency was 412 ms, representing a 47.2% reduction relative to Ramesh et al. (781 ms) and a 26.8% reduction compared to Sharma et al.43 (563 ms). The latency gains are attributable to reduced block payload sizes, parallelized IPFS retrieval, and an optimized consensus configuration tuned for healthcare transaction patterns. The empirical results confirm that EHRChain maintains high throughput and low latency under concurrent load conditions typical of real-world healthcare environments. The hybrid consensus protocol, combined with off-chain IPFS storage, delivers a balanced performance profile that addresses both the scalability limitations of fully on-chain systems and the latency constraints of cloud-based hybrids. Consequently, the framework is well-positioned for deployment in scenarios demanding real-time, privacy-preserving, and high-volume medical data exchange.

The security proof our proposedEHRChain model involves a thorough evaluation to ensure its robustness against potential vulnerabilities. EHRChain utilized the open-source tool Oyente, which applies symbolic execution techniques to scrutinize smart contracts by executing functions step by step. Oyente operates exclusively with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) and does not require access to high-level representations like Solidity or Serpent. Our focus was on bolstering the security of a blockchain-based healthcare system designed for managing Electronic Health Records (EHRs) securely. Step 1. In frame number 1, Alice is a healthcare provider who interacts with a critical smart contract in our blockchain healthcare system that handles the access control to patient records. The goal was to employ strong security practices to protect patient data privacy, correctness, and availability. Step 2. we chose Oyente, as it has the ability to symbolically execute and systematically explore paths in Ethereum smart contracts. Insolvency for example, If contract malicious user invokes it – This would allow for detailed examination of possible entry points for attacks like reentrancy, integer overflow or underflow, out-of-gas errors, unexpected state changes and cross-function state changes, etc. Step 3. The step-by-step simulation performed by Oyente explores different execution paths and input variations to find vulnerabilities. During this audit, it found a critical reentrancy vulnerability in the access control function of our smart contract. An attacker named Bob could use recursive calls to adjust privileges and attack the program using this vulnerability. Step 4. After discovering the reentrancy vulnerability, our development team applied the “Checks-Effects-Interactions” pattern in the code of the smart contract. This guarantees that all critical functions begin with condition validation (Checks), state modification based upon validated conditions (Examples), and secure external interaction handling (Interactions). This added a layer of protection only an internal call to the guard would let the process continue, and when reentrancy was detected it would revert the entire transaction. Step 5. After implementing the mitigation strategies, we re-executed Oyente to check if our mitigation strategies were effective. Later reports showed a marked decrease in flagged vulnerabilities, a sign that the effort was leading to an enhanced security posture and greater resilience to the common threats faced by blockchain projects. Step 6. This work illustrates how the use of Oyente for tool-based assessment allowed to discover serious vulnerabilities and in addition to address their effective mitigation in our blockchain-based healthcare system. This perspective safeguards patient data saved onboard development while also navigating developing security hazards.

The security analysis, illustrated in Fig. 9, indicates that the majority of the outputs in the analysis report are “False,” which means that the smart contract in our proposed model is resilient against many well-known vulnerabilities. This underscores the robustness and security of the proposed model. However, the analysis revealed vulnerabilities in two areas: integer overflows and integer underflows. Both of these vulnerabilities are manageable and temporary. An integer overflow occurs when the number of integers required to execute a function exceeds the specified limit, while an underflow occurs when the number of integers falls below the threshold necessary for the function to run properly.
